Your sword was called Fang, its handle was made from the finest gold while the blade was carved from a tooth taken from the great dragon, Smaug. News of the sword's creation spread quickly as tales have spoke of Smaug possessing untold magic, explaining his 'invulnerability'. Upon bringing Fang to bear, its blade ignited in a bright orange flame and the sound of 'breathing' echoed from it.

"Your sword, though powerful, will do little to tip the odds, boy!" said the one, returning his sword to its sheath. "You have received your one warning. The next time we meet, you will not see us coming."

With that said, the four Ringwraiths rode passed you and Murder, vanishing from sight as they did. Only, with Fang still at the ready, you alone could hear their horses ride off into the distance. Once you could no longer hear them, you sheathed your sword, its fire and 'breathing' silenced. "They are gone." you said.

Murder slowly turned to you, her face ashen with fear, before turning red with annoyance. "You are either very brave or very foolish, young Cire." she scolded.

She then quickly explained who the Ringwraiths were and what they were capable of, causing you to turn pale. "We had better move on then." you said. "Please lead, I am obviously unworthy."

Murder, seeing that your regret was genuine, sighed before managing a small grin. "As I said, you have much to learn." she told you. "Your sword, Fang, will give you an edge but I expect you to heed my warnings in the future, understand!?"

You swallowed hard, taken back by Murder's sharp tone. "Yes, Murder." you replied, quickly.

Murder nodded. "Let's move on, then."

Your journey continued.
15212122.title: A warning from the Ringwraiths.

152121221.content:
The remainder of your ride to Hobbiton was uneventful only you sensed that Murder was constantly on her guard, all of her senses seemed to have been on full alert. You decided to remain on guard as well, better safe than dead. upon reaching Hobbiton, you and Murder found that it had been attacked. Doors to the small houses were shattered and belongings were seen strewn about. You immediately knew where the four Ringwraiths had rode from.

"What could those devils have possibly found here?" I asked.

Murder frowned. "The ring of Smaug."

My eyes nearly bugged out of my head, hearing that. "Smaug had a ring!?"

Murder dismounted in front of Frodo's house and urged me to do the same. "You know that when your father was recovering 'black arrow', the weapon that killed Smaug, he also claimed one of the dragon's fangs." she said. "At this time, Gandalf the grey used the ring of fire to steal Smaug's resurrection magic and trapped it into a cursed ring."

"With that ring, someone could bring Smaug back!?" I asked, stunned.

Murder shook her head. "With that, Smaug could bring himself back." she told me, darkly. "He would use the bearer of the ring as his new body, reshaping it into his old form and living again with the ring bearer no longer existing."

I tried to say something but Murder cut me off. "The ring is evil and gives off a 'pulse' similar to the rings of doom."

"Which is why we were sent to retrieve it." you replied, darkly. "Because it will lure those dark horsemen away from the fellowship of the ring."

Murder nodded. "You learn fast, young Cire." she said. "However, it is not my first choice to join that mission. Our job is to take the ring to Lord Elron and leave him to assemble a team to that task."

You nodded then followed Murder into the house where we found Frodo, waiting for us. I winced, seeing a splint on his left leg. "It is not as painful as it looks." he said. "However, it is definitely broken... I can not join you on your quest."

"Do you still have the ring?" asked Murder.

Frodo nodded. "I have it but only prince Cire may carry it." he replied. "These are orders directly from Gandalf the wizard, I dare not evoke his wrath." he reached into his pocket, producing a gold band on a gold chain. "My lord, I was instructed to tell you never to wear this ring on your finger."

"I understand." you said, taking the chain. "I was told of Smaug's resurrection magic."

Again Frodo nodded. "My lord..."

"Please, just Cire." you said, patiently. "This mission is too important to be distracted by titles."

"Very well... Cire." said Frodo, slightly impressed. "Could you please give us some privacy? Murder's family had sent a currier who ordered me to convey message to her."

You nodded then bowed your way out of the house. Once alone, Frodo turned to Murder, serious. "The message is short but clear. Do not allow Smaug to return, regardless of the cost."

Murder looked out the window, spotting you, then turned to Frodo and quietly nodded. "Let us hope Cire is strong enough not to be taken by the ring's power."

"Gandalf assured me that Cire's kind heart will offer him some protection." said Frodo. "However, he is human. Help keep his mind focused on the mission at hand."

Minutes later, Murder left Frodo's house and you were back on your horses, riding back to Rivendell with all due speed.
152121221.title: Reaching Hobbiton.

1521212212.content:
Once Murder and I were a mile from Hobbiton, she motioned for you to stop. "I do not want any secrets between us, if we are to work as a team." she said. "The message my family had given me was short but clear... Do not allow Smaug to return, regardless of the cost."

I immediately knew hat she meant as I was the one bearing the ring on a chain around my neck. "I promise you that I am strong enough not to be tempted by its power." I told her. "Only a complete fool would wear such a ring."

"The Ringwraiths were such fools." said Murder. "You will be tempted, young Cire. Keep their fate in mind and you might have a chance to walk away from this, still a human."

I smiled at her. "I have faith in my strength, my courage..." I drew my sword. "...and Fang."

The blade once again ignited into flames with the sound of 'breathing' emitting from it. Only Murder turned slightly pale as the ring ignited with it and she caught a glimpse of the old dragon's face over my own! It was only a shadow, a reflection, but it was enough to cause her to grip her own sword. "Never draw your sword unless you intend to use it!" she snapped. "Put it back in its sheath before I'll give you a scare to remember your mistake!"

Startled, I quickly drove Fang back into its sheath and saw that Murder had relaxed considerably. I did not feel the ring ignite into flame nor did I have any clue that she had seen Smaug's face over my own. "I had no intention of attacking." I assured her. "Please, be calm."

Murder sighed. "The drawing of Fang reacted with the ring." she told me. "I saw Smaug's face over your own, it was enough to cause me alarm."

I shivered at that thought. "I'll bear that in mind." I replied. "Thank you."

"We best move on with all haste." said Murder. "The ring is no doubt attracting those who are searching for it."

I nodded and pushed Arwen to hurry along with Murder commanding Avata to quickly follow. Neither she or I were aware that the ring had already caught the attention of one miserable creature. He hurried after us as best he could on foot, following our trail... "My precious!"
1521212212.title: A glance at Smaug.

15212122121.content:
Murder and I arrived in Rivendell in reasonable time and took the ring of Smaug directly to Elron. "Our mission was successful, my lord." said Murder, bowing to the elven king. "Cire bears Smaug's ring around his neck."

"Any problems along the way?" asked Elron.

"We encountered four of the Ringwraiths." I replied. "They were lured to Hobbiton by the power of Smaug's ring. They all seemed shaken by sword, Fang."

Elron paled slightly but composed himself quickly. "I see." he said. "You are both to be lucky to be alive." he paused, turning to me. "The sword and the ring will react with each other, do not draw Fang unless you intend to use it."

I gave Murder a glance then turned back to Elron who nodded. "Ah, you have already learned this the hard way." he said. "Smaug's will is as powerful as he is evil, young Cire. This is his fifth resurrection since his birth over a thousand years ago on the top of Mt Doom."

I was stunned by that comment. "I knew elves had long lives but..."

Elron laughed. "I am not quite that old, young Cire." he said, amused. "It was my father who witnessed Smaug's birth." he then frowned. "It was he who had tracked down and slaughtered his mother for her willful destruction of the entire Rivendell valley, so long ago."

I swallowed hard. "What mission do you have in store for us, my lord?" I asked.

Elron cleared his throat. "You and murder will be joining the Fellowship on their quest." he replied. "They left earlier this morning so you have some catching up to do."

"Would it not be wiser to serve as a decoy group to give the real mission a better chance of success?" I asked.

Elron shook his head. "With two evil rings in the group, those hunting you down will be forced to hesitate before choosing which ring bearer to go after." explained Elron. "We Elves have known this for centuries... he who hesitates will die."

I bowed before the elven king. "As you wish it, my lord." i said. "I shall prep our horses for the mission."

"You are a noble man, Prince Cire." said Elron. "I realize that you dislike the use of titles but there is a chance I may never encounter you again so I pay my respects to you."

"Thank you, King Elron." I replied with the same respect. "I shall leave you now."

With that I left the throne chamber, unaware of the conversation between Elron and Murder. "Before you leave, Murder, you should know this." said Elron. "Three items are required to bring Smaug back from the dead, Cire has two of them. One, a sliver of the dragon's ivory."

"Cire's sword, 'Fang'." whispered Murder.

Elron nodded. "Second is the dragon's magic, captured with in a ring."

"Smaug's ring." said Murder, turning more pale.

"The third required item is a catalyst." said Elron. "An uncontrolled fire of rage."

"What will you have me do, king Elron?" asked Murder.

"Keep young Cire focused, Murder." said Elron, seriously. "In all my years, I have learned one certain thing about humans... the power of their rage is unfathomable and those who can control it are the ones you do not want angry."

Murder swallowed hard. "Cire is such a human." she thought. "I pray I can keep him together."

"May luck be with you and young Cire." said Elron. "You best be off."

Murder bowed before the elven king and hurried out of the throne chambers.
15212122121.title: Arriving in Rivendell.

choices: We stopped to rest the night.
152121221212.content:
After gathering all of the supplies we would need for our journey, I loaded Arwen with light supplies, wincing at his mild grunt protest to the added weight as I climbed on. "Sorry, boy." I said, patting my horse. "I need all of this."

Murder smiled as she mounted Avata with a single small bag and laughed, seeing my confused expression. "It's called a bottomless bag." she explained. "It's an enchanted bag that can hold as much of you want that will fit in the opening."

"How much does it weigh?" I asked, curious.

"Practically nothing." replied Murder with a giggle. "One of the advantages of elven magic."

I grunted, a small grin forming on my face. "Is that why Avata seems so underdeveloped?"

Murder gave a short laugh. "Is that a challenge to a race I hear?" she asked.

I grinned. "The first one to the southern edge of Rivendell Valley will be the victor." I told her.

"The loser will prepare supper tonight." challenged Murder. "I like vegetables on a skewer, browned but not dark."

"Its agreed." I said. "Ladies first."

Murder smiled then gave Avata a command in elven tongue. Avata gave out a loud cry, much like a laugh then, to my great surprise, unfolded a large pair of wings I had not noticed before. Avata took flight with Murder laughing, riding on her back as they flew towards the south, over the trees.

"I flying horse." I said, stunned. "Now I've seen everything.

With that, I gave my command and Arwen was off like lightning, tearing up the road.

That evening...
152121221212.title: Off to join the quest.

1521212212122.content:
You reached the southern most edge of Rivendell just as Murder was dismounting Avata. she looked at you, stunned, then smiled as you dismounted yourself. "I am impressed, young Cire." she said. "Not many horses can keep up with Avata."

You returned Murder's smile with a hint of pride. "Arwen is a Mustang." you said. "I have yet to meet any horse that can beat him... on land."

Murder giggled. "I admit, I slightly cheated by having Avata fly here." she said. "Therefore I will prepare our dinner tonight."

You shook your head. "No, no." you replied. "You are about to sample a taste of some real cooking, human style."

Murder gave you a sarcastic look, smiling. "You have never tasted Elven cooking in your life if you truly believe that human cooking is better." she said. "I can make you a dish that will literally met in your mouth."

"Is that a challenge you are offering me?" you asked. "I can cook a dish that will make you beg me for seconds and then thirds before wanting more."

Murder laughed. "Perhaps it is, young Cire." she replied. "You already know what I want as a dish, what of you?"

You returned Murder's laugh. "I accept your challenge, young lady." you said, causing a short 'huh!' to escape Murder's lips. "I will have the same dish so all will be equal." you then smiled. "The same rule applies, don't whine when I defeat you in making the better meal."

Murder smiled, looking you in the eye. "You are on... young man." she said.

With that, the cooking competition began. Who won?
1521212212122.title: Friendly rivalry.

15212122121221.content:
"I must admit defeat, young Cire." said Murder, smiling. "You are a prince and a fine cook. I never thought a human could make anything worth eating from what they find in the forest."

"We humans are more versatile than you give us credit for." you replied. "I must say, though, I would love to learn more about Elven food." you smiled. "It was very filling for something so little."

Murder laughed. "We Elves have centuries of experience." she said. "You humans will learn... eventually."

You were about to respond when your instincts alerted you that something was wrong. "The crickets..." you whispered.

Murder turned pale. "They fell silent, something is coming this way." she whispered back.

Without another word said, you and Murder abandoned the fire and hid inside a clump of bushes, just in time to see a number of mountain trolls enter the clearing. They looked around, sniffing the air, looking for the two of you. It was by bad luck alone one spotted Murder and hoisted her out of the bushes. She yelled in protest.

"Look what we have here, Chum." said the one who had Murder by the leg. "A little snack."

The other troll laughed, making your blood boil. You did not realize that Murder was waiting for her opportunity to strike. Her mistake was to forget that humans have a hair trigger temper when it came to protecting those they befriend.

"Release her, vermin!" you warned, showing yourself. "Do it now or taste my wrath!"

The two trolls laughed at you, making your blood boil even more. "Oh, do you have a crush on this little morsel?" asked the second troll, smiling cruelly. "Perhaps I'll let you watch as we eat her first."

They laughed again but fell silent as your rage reached new heights. You drew fang and griped the ring so not to lose it. Unfortunately, it was all that was needed to show Murder Elron's warning. Your entire body was immediately engulfed in flames from fang, though you did not feel it and terrifying face peered out of the flames that caused the trolls to freeze in utter horror. It was the face of Smaug! Murder's eyes widened as she too found herself gripped in fear. She quickly snapped out of it as the troll dropped her and slowly moved away so not to be noticed.

"If those trolls are smart, they'll back away too!" she thought. "Cire... control your rage!"

Only, to Murder's sigh, the two trolls decided to run for their lives and Smaug sent forth a blast of fire that not only sent the trolls to their doom but set fire to the forest. It was to their good graces that it started to pour down raining then as it was enough to calm Cire who re-sheathed fang, sending Smaug away. As he released the ring, however, he felt very weak and slumped to the forest floor with Murder running to him. She carefully checked him for injuries, Elron's words echoing in her head...

"In all my years, I have learned one certain thing about humans... the power of their rage is unfathomable and those who can control it are the ones you do not want angry."

That following morning...
15212122121221.title: You win but lose something else.

152121221212212.content:
You woke up minutes later, feeling pain in every joint of your body as if you had suddenly become and old man from merely touching the ring of Smaug. You moaned, catching the attention of Murder who moved to you. "Cire, talk to me." she said firmly but politely. "Do you remember what happened last night when the trolls attacked?"

You moaned again, nodding. "Remind me never to touch that ring again." you said, hoarsely. "What a rush, it felt as if someone was literally breaking through my body." you winced, moaning again. "I hurt everywhere."

Murder nodded then quickly drew her dagger and sliced it through your left nipple, forcing a scream that drove birds from the trees. "What did you do that for!?!" you screamed, furious. you were not yet aware of what Murder had done.

"I was tempted to cut it completely off, you fool!" Murder screamed back, magically sealing the wound. "This is your first warning, the damage will heal. The second will me more harsh!"

You growled then looked down at where she had stabbed you and screamed again, your left nipple was now a breast! "What sorcery is this!?!" you yelled.

"If you heed my warning and do not allow your rage to control you, that will flatten in time." said Murder, angrily. "If you continue to be a stubborn man, the second warning will make you a woman from the waist up." she then gave you a sly grin, causing you to shiver. "The final warning will give your father a princess to pamper and spoil."

For a moment, you turned red, feeling your blood boil then suddenly chuckled. "I remember this warning ritual." you said, looking at her. "If you can not take your life seriously, a new life will be given." you then turned glum. "I only wished to protect you, Murder. I... I knew of no other way."

Murder nodded, her smile broadening. "You truly are a humble man, Cire." she said. "You will remain a man so long as you heed my warning. All those who ask we will say you accidentally stabbed yourself with my witch-blade." she giggled before adding, "Young Slade made that mistake once and I gave him a set to remember the lesson. It took a month for him to return to normal, he looked good as a woman."

You laughed, imagining the scene. "I will heed your warning, Murder." you said. "In fact..." you took a small pouch from your pocket and emptied it into another then used it to hold the ring as it hung from your neck. "Now I can no longer physically hold the ring... I'd rather avoid wearing a corset."

Murder smiled. "How very wise of you."

Hours later....
152121221212212.title: You remember everything.

choices: You search the dead bodies of the Uruk hai for clues to why they are here
1521212212122122.content: You come across a company of orcs not far from the Fellowship. "They bear the White Hand of Saruman" you say, pointing to the helmets "They must be following the Fellowship" "Shall we go and say hello?" said Murder, a smile on her face. You returned her smile and brought out your bow. "I hear orc food burns pretty good" you say, aiming at a supply pack. Murder lit your arrow with magic and you fired. The effect was not what you expected. The food exploded and killed about half of the orc party. "Seriously, I think they stored their explosive powder for their demolition charges in there" said Murder "Lets get em" She ran out of her hiding place and slammed into what appeared to be the leader of the Uruk hai party. He was knocked over by the force of her collision. You pulled out your sword and joined her. Soon, you were fighting Uruk hai that were surrounding you. "Duck" shouted Murder. You did so. She put her hand on your back and jumped and ran around the Uruks, knocking them all over. You then ran around them, running your sword through all their necks. "Well" you say "That was fun"
1521212212122122.title: you come across a company of orcs

15212122121221222.content:
"I want to know why they were here." you said to Murder's nod. "Something about their presence was just to convenient."

As you searched, Murder watched the fellowship moving further ahead. "We might want to hurry, Cire." she said. "That is if we wish to catch up to them before next nightfall."

"We have them in sight and we know where they are heading." you replied, patiently, trying to ignore the new weight on your chest. "I need to know why these orcs were waiting for us."

Presently, you found a parchment with orders written down in blood. It was from Sauron himself. This puzzled you. This breed of orc had never been seen before, and they bore a mark of a white hand. You were unable to read the orders, as they were written in orcish. Murder, however, could read the language and translated it for you.

'Capture the ring of Smaug and the one who bears it. Kill all who stand in your way. With all the rings and the great dragon at my command, no soul shall dare oppose us!'

You swallowed hard, handing the parchment to Murder. "Our quest has just become more complicated." you said.

Murder sighed. "I knew Sauron was greedy for power but this..." she shook her head. "Our mission has not changed, we must help protect the fellowship and destroy the ring of Smaug."
15212122121221222.title: You search the dead bodies of the Uruk hai for ...

152121221212212221.content:
"Gandalf was wise not to allow us to serve as decoys." said Murder, mounting her horse. "He always knew more than he revealed." she waited for you to mount your horse before adding, "We ride!"

You and Murder rode swiftly through the forest trails, not daring to stop for an instant, knowing that you were both being tracked now as well. Fortunately, you both knew that there were safety in numbers and were pleased to find the fellowship, or what seemed like the fellowship, camped out in a low clearing just before sunset. "There they are." said Murder, coming to a stop. "We caught up to them."

"Wait a minute." you said, raising a hand. "None of them are standing guard while the others rest." you sighed, feeling nervous. "I don't like this...."

"I could shoot an arrow near them to see if they react." said Murder, quietly. "What do you think?"

What do you do?
152121221212212221.title: Meeting the fellowship.

1521212212122122211.content:
You nodded and Murder fired an arrow, carefully aiming for a nearby tree. As it came close, however, a tall and strong man turned from behind the tree and caught it with incredible skill. With a surprised look you immediately recognized him as King Bard, your father! "You have good aim, Murder." he called out with a smile. "Only you lack in force, a human should never be able to catch an elven arrow."

Murder smiled as she and you approached. "I was not using an elven arrow." she replied, simply. "You should not bathe in scents if you intend to remain hidden."

Bard blushed slightly. "I have forgotten elves have such acute senses." he said. "I am glad you two found your way to the fellowship in one piece." he then chuckled, turning to you. "I see you took a hit from a change blade. Don't get hit again unless you wish to wear a corset."

Murder giggled, causing you to blush. Bard turned to observe the Fellowship. "I am here at Lord Elrond's request," said Bard "His daughter went missing not long ago, he asked me to track her down and convince her to return to him."

"I take it she refused," said Murder, shaking her head slightly "No one tells Arwen Evenstar what to do."

"I'm going to tell Elrond that I couldn't convince her to return," said Bard "I can see that she really loves Aragorn, I'm not going to come between them, now, I must return to my kingdom. Good luck, my son, I wish you all the luck in the world."

With that, he vanished. Stunned, I looked around then looked up to Murder's pointing to see him fly off in the talons of a giant eagle. Murder sighed sadly. "Your father is close to the great fields, young Cire." she said quietly. "Are you certain you wish to continue?"

You teared up, knowing what Murder meant but slowly nodded. "My people are counting on me to stop this evil." you said. "I will not fail them."

"Well said, young human." said an elven woman, standing up from the group. "I am Arwen Evenstar, Elrond’s daughter. I joined this campaign against his best judgment."

"I am Cire, son of King Bard, and bearer of the ring of Smaug which I intend to destroy."
1521212212122122211.title: Fire an arrow.

choices: Stick with your plan and charge
15212122121221222112.content:
"We should keep moving," you say "We encountered some Ringwraiths in the road, now that we're together, my ring should mask Frodo's ring for a while, but it will not detain them for long" Arwen nodded, and picked up her equipment from the ground. The rest of the Fellowship also prepared to move off, Aragorn and Legolas helping the hobbits get ready. Once ready, the group moved off. Not long after you moved off, Aragorn saw Orc tracks leading into a clearing in the woods. When you went to investigate, you saw that the clearing was full of orcs. Worse, the orcs were tormenting human prisoners.
You drew your sword, keeping it muffled by your cloak. Aragorn put a hand on your arm, shaking his head.
"Too many," he said "We need to be cleverer about this."
15212122121221222112.title: your choice.

152121221212212221121.content:
"What do you suggest, Aragorn?" sheathing Fang, you asked. "I'm open to suggestions."

Aragorn frowned. "Bait to lure them to the river." pointing at the large river a few yards behind the group of Orcs, he said. "Are you a fast runner, Cire?"

"When chased by Orcs, yes." confident, you replied. "Only how will I avoid whatever trap you have in mind?"

"You let us worry about that." seriously, replied Aragorn. "You just charge in and run for the river. The Orcs love a moving target, they will follow you, especially since there is a reward out for your head."

You gulped slightly then nodded. "I can only hope your plan works." you said.

With that, you charged out, yelling your head off, to get the Orcs attention. It worked, almost too well, as they all saw you immediately and gave chase, babbling about rewards of gold. "Don't fail me now, legs!" running at your best seed, you yelled. "Come on, Aragorn, where is that trap!?"

You reached the water and began to quickly swim across, thankful you were a natural swimmer, with the Orcs blindly following you. Upon reaching the other side, you turned to see the Orcs half way across but struggling to move as if the mud on the bottom had gripped their ankles. Then the sound of angry water reached you and your turned to see the river wising in a huge wave. Knowing you would not be able to fight such a wave, you scrambled up a tree and watched in a sense of both awe and horror as the Orcs were all too easily swept away by the angry current before all was calm again and the waters were still.

"Note to self." shaking, you said. "Never anger an elven magic user."

Minutes later, you were back with the group, talking with the humans the Orcs once held prisoner.
152121221212212221121.title: Come up with a plan

1521212212122122211211.content:
As you got back to the abandoned orc camp, you saw that Aragorn and your other companions had freed the human prisoners. It was only then that you recognised the only female in the group.
"Henner?" you asked. The girl turned to look at you, her eyes brightening in recognition. She was a very pretty girl. Tall for a girl of Lake Town, she had been your friend since you were both kids.
"Cire," said Henner, breaking away from her companions and running towards you. She threw her arms around you in a friendly embrace. As you looked at your companions, you saw their surprise that you should know this girl.
"It was lucky that you found us in time," said Henner "The orcs were going to use us in some sort of magic ritual, but then their shaman was killed by one of our own, he was killed not long after that." Her voice cracked.
As you looked around, you saw other humans from Lake Town in Henner's group.
"What were you all doing here so far away from Lake Town?" you asked
"Smaug is not dead yet," said Henner "While his spirit lived, it is within our interests as well as yours to destroy him."
"Our group is getting too large," said Aragorn "We are too conspicuous for our purpose."
"We are all fighters," said another of Henners group "Why can't we help?"
"It's not that large a group," you say "We could still go unseen, Henner learned from Bard how to conceal herself as well as any Ranger, I expect the rest of the group are also experts at concealment, I've been away from Lake Town for a while."
"We won't be any trouble," said Henner "We can all hunt for ourselves, we've been able to since childhood."
"I think they should come," said Murder "They are experts in concealment, if they can conceal us in Mordor, we might have an advantage."

What do the Fellowship decide?
1521212212122122211211.title: continue.

15212122121221222112111.content:
"There is another issue... Your Majesty." with a pained look, Henner said.

"Henner, you know I do not like to be called by my official title." wincing, you said.

"I'm afraid it is now necessary... King Cire." tearing up, Henner replied. "Your father was slain by the ring wraiths, searching for the ring of Smaug. Dozens of our soldiers fell before them, leaving our kingdom in grief and rage."

Your eyes widened, filling with tears as the news hit you hard. Murder and the members of the fellowship bowed their heads in respect, as did Henner's four person group. "Father... was... slain?" slowly, you asked. "No...."

"We grieve for your loss... King Cire." softly, Aragorn said. "We would not think differently of you if you felt the need to take the throne in your father's place. We can carry the dragon's ring from here."

"No!" barely containing your rage, you said. "Henner, send the fastest rider of your group back to Lake Town and tell them it is my decree that my mother rule in my place until my return!"

Henner, seeing the stubborn determination in your eyes, bowed. "By your command, your majesty." she said.

Within minutes, a man rode at all speeds, back towards Lake Town with Henner and two others joining the fellowship.
"I was ordered to give this to you." retrieving an arrow with a black diamond head, Henner said.

"The black arrow." taking it from Henner, you said. "It never failed my father. I can only guess he never had the chance to use it against the ring wraiths."

"No, your majesty, he did not." sadly, Henner confirmed.

You sighed then turned to Murder. "As king of the Lake kingdom, I order you to hold onto the black arrow, Murder." your voice quivering, you ordered. "If Smaug should return through me, slay the damn dragon."

"You are either very courageous or very foolish, young Cire." holding back her tears, Murder thought. then she replied, "It shall be done... King Cire."

"We will follow at a hundred paces in a triangle formation to serve as lookouts." suggested Henner. "This way, there will be less of a chance of any surprise attacks."

"Then we move on." regaining your composure, you said. "Please refer to me as Cire, an equal to you all. Aragorn, I ask that you continue to take the lead, this quest is too important to risk it on an inexperienced... king."

Aragorn nodded but did not speak as words were not necessary at that point and the fellowship continued on its quest...
15212122121221222112111.title: King Cire.

choices: Draw the wargs in and destroy them
152121221212212221121111.content:
As night came, Henner and her scouts returned to the group.
"We found warg tracks around the area, they seemed to be going in a classic search pattern," said Henner "They must be looking for us."
"We need to do something unexpected," said Aragorn "Go somewhere that wargs can't follow."
"Either that, or we draw them out and take them down," said Legolas, his bow at the ready as if he was ready to go warg hunting right away.
"We can't go now," said Gandalf "They have excellent night vision, we'd be at a disadvantage if they caught any of us on our own tonight."
"We should keep a close formation then," said Murder "No more scouting out the land for a few days, at least, you said we should do something unexpected, so lets head for the mountain."
"Go over the mountain?" said Boromir incredulously "That's suicide!"
"Who said we should go over the mountain?" said Murder, coolly, "My intention could have been to go under it."
"It's something to consider," said Aragorn "Gandalf, Murder has a point, we could easily lose the wargs underground."
"It's not the wargs i'm worried about," said Gandalf. You waited, expecting him to elaborate, but he did not.
"I agree with Murder," you say "Going under the mountain might be our only option to avoid the warg packs."
"We will follow you... Cire," said Henner, as the warriors with her nodded.
"My cousin Balin recently made an expedition into Moria," said Gimli "We could perhaps take advantage of his hospitality."

What do the fellowship decide?
152121221212212221121111.title: continue.

choices: The other wargs attack in force
You go into the clearing and remove the bodies of the dead wargs
1521212212122122211211112.content:
The plan was made. At about midday, the Fellowship spread out, twenty paces between each person. Each person held a ranged weapon. You, Murder and Henna's troop, as well as Aragorn and Legolas carried bows. The hobbits held stones. Gimli held one of his throwing axes. Boromir did not have a ranged weapon, but was experienced at fighting wargs in close combat. They then lit a fire in a clearing and put some bad meat on it. Then, they all concealed themselves in the forest around the camp fire. As the first warg came into the clearing, it's nose in the air, you let loose an arrow, right through its neck. It fell to the ground with a thump, muffled by the heather placed around the campfire. One of Henner's men ran into the clearing to make sure the warg was dead, signaled that it was, then ran back into hiding. You had some reservations about the men checking the wargs, their scents could be tracked if they moved over the same path too frequently, so you agreed to their checking on the agreement that they find a new hiding place following the death check. From her position up a nearby tree, Murder gestured to an area of bush. A wargs head stuck into the clearing, and was immediately felled with an arrow in the eye. Henner and her men didn't even bother to go check this one. You signed to Murder.
"How many are there left?"
Murder held up eight fingers. You nodded and refocused your attention on the clearing, only to jump backwards at the face of a warg. You quickly brought your bow up and shot an arrow at the warg just as it was about to roar at you. The arrow came clean out the back of the warg's throat and kept going, somehow, it hit another warg that had just peeked into the clearing from the other side. The entire fellowship was shocked at what happened, even you.
1521212212122122211211112.title: Draw the wargs in and destroy them

15212122121221222112111121.content:
A loud orc horn rang out from the surroundings. Orcs and wargs charged in, surrounding and outnumbering the fellowship as they continued to fight. It was a move you had seen before when fighting against the forces of Khand in the east, but you had not thought these orcs and wargs would have thought of it. The wargs would scout the area, using their silent language to communicate, and when they found the enemy, they would scout their position and then call in their masters to surround their enemy. They were snarling and howling as they ran forward in a blind rage to avenge their fallen mounts. You had fought a warg pack before but not one so blood driven for revenge as these. You managed to keep the beasts at bay but you also had the wargs coming your way. "This is fun, eh, Murder?" sarcastically, you asked.

"Remind me to discuss your meaning of fun later, Cire." punching a wolf in the head, Murder replied.

Boromir threw a warg off with his shield then drove his sword through its rider, pushing him off. "We are wasting time here!" annoyed, he said. "Let's finish with these creatures and move on!"

Just then, a warg managed to grab Murder by the wrist and bite down. She screamed, more startled than hurt, then kicked the warg off. Still, it was enough for an orc to thrust his sword at Murder. It only grazed her shoulder but, from your angle, it looked as if it had pierced her heart as she fell back with blood spewing onto the crude blade. "NO!" enraged, you screamed. "Bastard!"

In your rage, you did not notice the other orc who thrust his sword at your chest. Only, to his great misfortune, the tip of the blade hit the ring of Smaug you had around your neck. The ring burned hot as you drew Fang in response. "Taste my wrath!"

Murder, who had dodged the warg and the orc, made short work of the two then turned to see the human rage Elron had warned her about. With her elven senses, she could almost see the heat from your blind fury as you rose your burning sword, Fang. "The three elements are in place." turning pale, she said. "Smaug is returning!"

Only, to her surprise and relief, Smaug appeared as a ghost rather than flesh and blood. It hissed at the suddenly pale panicked wargs, steam pouring from its mouth. "You insignificant incests!" with a hiss, it roared. "How dare you bar my path to destiny! BURN!"

With that, a ghostly fire spewed from Smaug's mouth, engulfing the wargs and their riders. It did no damage but it was more than enough to send the superstitious creatures running for their lives. Once they were no longer a threat, Smaug vanished, leaving you standing in the middle of the field, looking thoughtful.

"Why did Smaug not return?" shaken and confused, you asked aloud. "Why did he not take my life to renew his own?" you looked down at yourself and noticed that you still had one female breast. the answer became obvious.

"Cire, are you injured?" walking up to you, Murder asked.

"No, I'm fine." quickly, you replied. "I have found a way to keep Smaug from returning." pausing, you then asked, "Are you injured, I saw that warg thrust his sword through you."

"He missed by a hair, I can take care of myself." with a slight smile, Murder said. "How can we stop Smaug from returning before we destroy the ring?"

"Smaug needs a man to possess in order to return." ruefully, you replied. "It was due to my one female breast that kept him from taking me over."

Murder smiled, touching the hilt of her elven sword. "You realize that, once you are female, it will take a month for you to change back into a man." bemused, she said.

"I'd rather live my life as a princess and grow up to be queen than to see that worm, Smaug curse this land again." firmly, you said. "Do it before I come to my senses."

Murder drew her elven sword. "As you wish... princess." giggling, she said.

With that, she thrust her blade...
15212122121221222112111121.title: The other wargs attack in force

152121221212212221121111211.content:
"We should keep moving." surprised by your new voice, you said. "The others are counting on us to destroy both rings."

"You should first change your clothes." serious, Murder said. "What you are wearing will not do."

You blushed slightly to the snickers and followed Murder behind a tall clump of bushes. "If any man dares to peek at the princess, you will join her feminine fate." giving an icy glare, she warned.

With that said, she led you behind the bushes where she ordered to yo strip down to the skin. You did so, blushing brightly, and Murder offered you some of her spare clothing. "Its a good thing my father made me take extra garments." smiling, she said. "He always had a certain foresight."

The ladies undergarments felt strange against your skin but at least they were comfortable. The corset, however, left much to be desired as Murder squeezed and crushed your midsection to the point where you had to gasp for breath. "Is this really necessary!?" complaining, you asked.

"Most women do not like these." serious, Murder said. "However, yes, it is necessary."

"I have a better idea." after a thought, you said. "Get this thing off me."

Curious, Murder helped you out of the corset and held it up as you had requested. Before she could react, you took Fang and sliced the garment in half. "That's all that is needed." returning Fang to its sheath, you said. "Let me have it."

Upon taking the top part of the destroyed corset, you put it on and saw that it held up your new breasts just fine without having to crush your body. "Much better." smiling, you said.

Murder looked at you for a moment then giggled. "What a novel idea." impressed, she said. "What would you call this new garment?"

"A breast restriction apparatus or bra." after a pause, you replied.

Murder laughed. "Very well, Cire." amused, she said. "Let's finish getting you dressed."

Moments later, you and Murder walked out from behind the bushes and everyone saw you were dressed as....
152121221212212221121111211.title: continue.

1521212212122122211211112111.content:
As you walked out, wearing simple elven garments with armour over them and an elven blade in a scabbard on the opposite side to your sword Fang. Murder had offered you an elven helmet, but you had rejected it, you had never fought with shield or helmet before now, and you weren't going to start now. It had also been Murder that had suggested the second sword. It carried similar enchantments to her witch blade, but modified slightly to only affect you, working as a counterbalance to the Ring of Smaug.
"You look beautiful... my lady," said Heather, as the hunters with her just stared. She noticed and smacked both of them across the face "Behave."
"Shall we move on?" you asked "Where are we heading?"
"We must go over the mountain," said Gandalf "It is the quickest way."
"I don't know, Gandalf," said Murder "The mountain is in Saruman's domain, he could make trouble for us, we don't know if these wargs and orcs were working alone or under the command of Saruman, I suggest we make for the gap of Rohan, in the short term, it'll take us longer than going over the mountain, in the long term, it'll probably be quicker and the safest route."
"I agree with Murder," said Boromir "My kinsmen have had good relations with the people of Rohan, perhaps they can give us some aid."
"The Gap of Rohan will take us too close to Isengard," said Aragorn "If Saruman would attack us here, and the orcs really swear allegiance to him, going close to his front door could be just as perilous as going over the mountain."
"Then which is the lesser of the two perils?" you asked, clearing your throat slightly, not yet being used to your new voice.
"I do not know," said Aragorn "We expose ourselves to attack from Saruman either way, I'm not sure which is the better option."
"We should vote on it," said Heather
"I agree," said Gandalf
1521212212122122211211112111.title: an Elven warrior.

15212122121221222112111121112.content:
"I suggest we go through the mountain, using the tunnels the goblins used when mining the mountains for the death rocks." speaking up, Gimli said. "Even if there are still goblins about, they know of the ring of Smaug and they would not dare risk its resurrection."

"We do not know enough about those tunnels to easily navigate them." patiently, Gandalf argued. "We could end up lost for weeks before exiting on the other side."

"By then, it will be too late." darkly, Murder said.

"I know those tunnels." surprising everyone, you said. "My father and I worked out a treaty with the goblins after the battle at Lonely Mountain."

"Did they give you a tour of the tunnels?" unimpressed, Gandalf asked. "Do you remember them all?"

"They gave us a map." serious, you replied. "My father and I checked the authenticity of it with the Dwarves who originally used those tunnels to escape the goblins on their way to defeat Smaug."

"Really?" showing surprise, Gandalf asked. he took the map and examined it. "Well, it is authentic."

"So we have a third option." nodding, Boromir said. "Which do you all think? The gap of Rohan or the old goblin tunnels?"

After a quick vote, the group decided on...
15212122121221222112111121112.title: Gimli suggests a third option

152121221212212221121111211122.content:
It was decided to move through the old Goblin tunnels. They were a literal maze, filled with death traps to deal with intruders. Those without a treaty map, showing the safe path through, would be lost for weeks, if they survived the traps. You were confident in the treaty with the Goblins as your people provided them with wine in exchange for safe passage straight through to avoid days of travel.

"Do not wonder into any of the tunnels except where I lead you." sternly, you ordered. "The goblins will not harm anyone through this one tunnel but those who stray off it are fair game."

"Was that part of the treaty?" curious, Murder asked.

You nodded. "The goblins are a hostile, distrusting lot; but so are humans." serious, you said. "My father told them that the action of one should not doom an entire group. Instead, if one wanders, he is to be considered a loner."

"This a rather harsh agreement but it does save the group as a whole from the stupidity of one." darkly, Gandalf said. "Remain in single file, do not stray from the one in front of you."

"I have a feeling we are being watched." looking about, Boromir said.

"That is because you are." serious, Murder replied. "This is the home for many goblin tribes. They have every right to be curious of anyone venturing into their territory."

You paused, seeing a massive figure in the path ahead of you. It was a goblin guard; he wore heavy leather armor and carried an impressive battle axe in his powerful hand. "Greetings, Tor." raising one hand, you said. "I am.... King Cire under an Elven blade enchantment."

The goblin looked at you curiously then laughed. "Then you should address yourself as Queen Cire." amused, he said in a deep voice. "What proof do you have to be 'King Cire'?"

You motioned to Murder who handed you the black arrow of which you held up for Tor to see. "I now bear the weight of the black arrow." solemnly, you said. "My mission is to destroy the ring of Smaug so the beast may never again rise to terrorize this land."

Tor bowed his head, showing a form of respect. "Your father, King Bard, was an honorable human." looking at you, he said. "It is rare to find such humans."

"Will you allow us to pass?" returning the black arrow to Murder, you asked.

Tor nodded. "I will allow you and your caravan to pass." softly, he said. "Be warned, however, danger lies ahead. I have been posted here to warn all allies of this threat."

"What threat?" curious, Murder asked.

Tor looked at Murder then you but nodded as you said, "She is my second in command."

"While mining for more death rocks, we... found a sleeping beast." darkly, Tor replied. "The safe path comes dangerously close to the pit where this creature sleeps." after a pause, he added, "It remains asleep so be certain not to awaken it."

"What is this creature?" asked Murder.

"Does it matter?" stepping aside, Tor asked. "If you awaken the beast, it will be grumpy and, no doubt hungry for food."

"We will be the main course if we wake it up." understanding, Murder said. "Thank you, Tor, for the friendly warning."

Tor nodded and allowed the group to pass.
152121221212212221121111211122.title: the goblin tunnels.

choices: The dragon settling back down to sleep
The dragon flying up the stairs after you
1521212212122122211211112111221.content:
We reached the edge of the pit. Before we moved on, you were curious to see what the beast was. You leaned over the pit, looking down. A black dragon was lying below, on top of a pile of Mithril. Weapons of mithril surrounded the dragon. It was not as big as Smaug, but it could be just as deadly.

"We should leave," you said "We don't want it to wake up." Suddenly, you heard a scrabbling, and saw Pippin slip and fall down a set of hidden steps into the pit, making a lot of noise as he did.
"Fool of a Took," said Gandalf, shaking his head. You started down the steps to where Pippin had gotten up. You ran over to him and then made for the steps. Suddenly, your foot pushed down a tile hidden in the dust.
"Cire, look out!" shouted Murder. You looked around wildly, and threw yourself to the ground just in time to avoid six arrows coming out of hidden slots in the walls to either side. However, as you fell, you pushed down another pressure plate. Now on your back, you saw a cage falling from the ceiling towards you. You quickly picked up Pippin and ran for the stairs. The cage missed you by inches, but landed with a resounding clang. You continued running with Pippin up the stairs as you heard a roar. When you reached the top, you turned to see...
1521212212122122211211112111221.title: Reaching the pit.

choices: Haldir, one of the border patrol of Lothlorien
15212122121221222112111121112212.content:
"The dragon is awake!" drawing her dagger, Murder yelled.

The black dragon gave a roar but paused, flapping its wings in a state of hover, staring directly at you. "You bear the ring of Smaug." in a deep voice, the dragon hissed. "What are your intentions!?"

"I am Cire, son of Bard." out of habit, you replied. "My intentions are to destroy the ring of Smaug before the worms power can be used to serve evil."

The dragon hissed out a laugh. "You have been 'blessed' by an elven blade." amused, it hissed. "That is fortunate for you as Smaug needs a man to resurrect himself."

The dragon landed with a heavy thump onto a stone pillar, its fiery red eyes still fixed upon you until Murder spoke. "We must continue on to Mount Doom so to destroy the ring." she said.

The dragon turned to her, hissing but you called its attention back onto you. "Do you know of a way to get closer without alerting Sauron?" loudly, you asked. "He wishes to obtain the ring to add to the rings of doom and increase his power."

"Sauron is a fool if he thinks he can control so much power." darkly, the dragon hissed. "I will help you but consider this... Cire... 'daughter' of Bard."

"I'm listening, dragon." annoyed to be called 'daughter', you said.

"Smaug needs a man to possess to bring himself back." repeated the dragon. "However, should a woman bring about the resurrection, she would force Smaug to adapt to her body and she would steal his power, becoming a force to be reckoned with."

"What have you heard of Laketown?" asked Henner "We must know what is happening there."

"I know much," said the dragon "I have foreseen Saruman's treachery for many ages, he has sent a great many spies to Laketown, I believe he is planning an invasion, a test for his new army."

"Who defends Laketown?" asked Gandalf

"King Bard's widow is preparing the town defence, with a second line in the shadow of Erebor," said the dragon "Laketown will not survive without our aid, there are three allies that may be able to defeat Saruman's threat, Beorn the Bear, Radagast the Brown, and myself, Chrysophyllax the Tame Worm."

"Your Chrysophyllax?" asked Pippin "The Tame Worm? I read your story."

"It was not a story," said Chrysophyllax "The town of Ham is the same as the Shire, just under a different name, your Fellowship must split up, find the allies needed to stop the destruction of Laketown, perhaps it was fate that brought you to me, but now, I wish to help to defend Laketown."

"We cannot stop," said Aragorn "The Ring of Sauron must be destroyed, we must continue to Mordor."

"There is another option," said Gandalf "We split up, Cire, the scouts from Laketown, and Murder go to the defence of Laketown, I go in search of Radagast the Brown, while they go to the hideout of Beorn the Bear, I shall then return to the company of the Ring, while Cire and his companions go to the defence of their town."

"Whatever you decide," said Chrysophyllax "We must decide quickly, the elves of Lothlorien will not welcome a dragon here."

"Do not be so certain that the elves will not accept you," said a voice "We know of your past, Lord Chrysophyllax, and of the prophecy, we welcome you to Lothlorien."

Who has spoken?
15212122121221222112111121112212.title: The dragon flying up the stairs after you

choices: To the hideout of Beorn the Bear
Gandalf gives your group some information about Beorn before leaving
152121221212212221121111211122121.content:
The company had been moving for days through Moria. They had planned to stay for a few days in Lothlorien to recover their strength, now that Chrysophyllax was welcome in Lorien, you, along with the company of the rings, proceeded with Galadriel to the wood elves capital, Caras Galadon. There, you and the company relaxed for a few days. It was on one of the nights, when the rest of the company was sleeping, that you awoke to see Galadriel beckoning you. You followed her to a clearing, where what looked like a large basin.
"Will you look into the mirror?" asked Galadriel
"What will I see?" you asked
"The mirror shows many things," said Galadriel "Things that were, things that are, and some things that have not yet come to pass."
You looked down into the dark water. It rippled, and then, you saw Laketown, and it was on fire. You saw man and dwarf running about, fighting against a strange breed of orc. Then, you saw the worst. You saw your father, old, and vulnerable, standing before a great dragon, leaning on a stick with one hand and holding a sword with the other, but he did not strike. He fell to his knees before Smaug. He opened his mouth, and Bard the Bowman was no more than ash.
"No!" you shouted, tearing your gaze away from the mirror, just as it changed back to dark, rippling water.
"I know what it is you saw," said Galadriel "For it is also in my mind, it is what will come to pass, should you fail. The quest to destroy the Ring of Smaug will also require you saving Laketown, for if Laketown is attacked, Smaug's coming will be much sooner."
"What of the Ring of Sauron?" you asked "Without the protection of our company, it will not reach Mordor."
"I do not wish harm to the hobbit," said Galadriel "But Frodo will soon have to continue his quest alone, there are already those in the company of the ring who would take the ring for their own, your quests are separate, so your fellowship must divide, if you do not, both quests will fail."

When it was time to leave, Galadriel gave each member of both Fellowships gifts, to Murder, she gave a magical orb, imbued with the same magical properties as the staves of the Istari, Murder's preference for fighting without weapons had made her adverse to using a staff. To Henner, she gave a modified bow, woven from a willow tree by herself personally, to the two hunters with Henner, she gave swords of Elven make. Finally, to you, she gave a sword, imbued with the elven rune of ice. This sword had two special purposes, the first was that it counteracted the sword Fang when used at the same time as it, the second, was that it froze any enemy slashed by it in a block of ice. It sensed the thoughts of its user, so it would know if the person fighting against its user was friend or foe. You thanked Galadriel for her gift, as she turned to Chrysophyllax.
"What gift would a dragon ask of the elves?" she asked
"Your hospitality and kindness are all the gift I need," he said "For my kin are hated by many people, it was nice to be shown kindness."
"Then I offer you my hospitality if ever you should be wanting, for as long as the people of Lorien can offer it," said Galadriel "Be warned, the Ring of Smaug is powerful, and the prospect of becoming Smaug out of a will to do good will tempt you, but the evil of Smaug will eventually corrupt Cire, and he will become worse than him. If Cire becomes Smaug, as either a man or woman, you must kill him."
This she said telepathically to Chrysophyllax, you only found out about it much later on.
"Good luck on your quest, I hope that you save Laketown," said Galadriel.
152121221212212221121111211122121.title: Galadriel, queen of Lothlorien

1521212212122122211211112111221212.content:
Just as you and Murder led your now smaller group away from Lorien on horseback, Gandalf appeared in your path with his arms spread in a gesture that commanded you and Murder to stop your horses in their tracks. "You need to know that the Ring-wraiths have visited Beorn the night before, looking for the ring of Smaug." Darkly, he said. "He managed to fight them off due to a power even I did not know he possessed."

"Are you telling us not to travel to Beorn's cabin?" Curious, Murder asked.

Gandalf shook his head. "No; proceed there but do not stay long." Firmly, he replied. "Beorn plans to travel back into the mountains when the full moon returns."

"Why does he wish to travel into Orc territory?" Concerned, you asked.

Gandalf smiled. "He has found more like him and he wishes to be among them." Simply, he replied. He then turned serious once more. "Beorn will not wait for you so travel quickly. He will take you through the mountains far enough to place you within reach of Mt Doom before he leaves to reunite with his people in the reverse mountains."

"Reverse mountains?" Confused, you asked.

"Mountains in an immense cavern system deep underground." Serious, Murder explained. "Not even Orcs dare travel there as it is said it is the birth place of rock people or rock golems."

"Beorn's people were not killed by the Orcs, they simply moved underground." Softly, Gandalf said. He stepped to the side. "Now off with you, all of you. As I had said, Beorn will not wait!"

You and Murder commanded your horses forward and lead your team down the wooded path toards Beorn's cabin at all speeds. "I wonder what power Gandalf referred to when he spoke of Beorn." Curious, you said.

"Some things are best not to ask." Serious, Murder replied. "Beorn is a trusted friend of Gandalf, his word is his bond."
1521212212122122211211112111221212.title: Gandalf gives your group some information about...

15212122121221222112111121112212122.content:
No more than ten minutes into the journey, Murder and you exchange a knowing look and suddenly change directions with the others following in confusion. "Why are we not going to Beorn's cabin as Gandalf instructed?" Curious, Heather asked.

"That was not Gandalf." Darkly, Murder replied. "That was Sauron. Our mission is to defend the Lake Valley kingdom at all costs."

"May I ask why?" Pressing, one of the huntsmen asked.

"Smaug did not target Lonely Mountain for its treasure." In a dead tone, you explained. "He targeted it because of what was buried below it."

"A piece of an ancient machine." Frowning, Murder said. "The King under the mountain called it 'The heart of the mountain'. It is actually the heart of the machine."

"What exactly does this machine do?" Worried, another huntsman asked.

"It transforms the world." Darkly, you replied. "Through ancient texts, my father and I discovered that there was a world before Middle Earth and the machine changed it into the world we now know."

"How do you know Sauron is after this machine?" Startled, Heather asked.

"Its powered by the rings he so desperately wants." Gulping, Murder said. "However, the machine is useless without the heart of the machine."

"It also explains why he is after the ring of Smaug." Darkly, you added. "He need something to guard the machine until he uses it."
15212122121221222112111121112212122.title: Something happens on the way.

152121221212212221121111211122121221.content:
"I thought the Ring Wraiths had the other rings." Confused, another huntsman said.

"They do." Serious, Murder said. "The rings feed off of them and the machine feeds off of the rings. Sauron created the Ring Wraiths to 'charge' the rings so they could power the machine."

"What of the last ring and the ring of Smaug?" Riding closer, Heather asked. "Does Sauron intend to destroy himself to work this machine."

"Not quite." Echoing, a female voice replied. "The one ring is the key to activate the machine which is powered by the others. The Ring of Smaug is to bring back a dragon to defend the machine until it changes the world to Sauron's will."

You and Murder brought your horses to a halt with the others following, looking around for the source of the echoing voice."Who are you!?" Hand on your elven sword, you demanded. "Show yourself!"

The feminine voice giggled. "I see you have your father's impatience... princess Cire." she said.

With that, a feminine figure appeared.....
152121221212212221121111211122121221.title: A new member to the group.

choices: Cire and his companions travel to Helm's Deep
Cire and his companions stay their current course
1521212212122122211211112111221212211.content:
The elven woman seemed to step out of one of the trees beside you, as she removed her elven cloak and placed it around her shoulders. She wore brown, leather armor over a green tunic and leggings, with brown boots. Her hair was red and shoulder length.
"Calm yourself, Prince Cire," said Murder "Let me introduce my sister, Tauriel."
"Adopted sister," said Tauriel, sheathing the long knife she had been holding "We served together in one of the ranger patrols in Mirkwood, but she wanted to explore the world, so she left."
Murder walked up and hugged her adopted sister. Only then, when you saw that the woman did not wish the company harm, did you sheathe your blade, and signal to Henner and the others to do the same.

"You were right to mistrust me," said Tauriel "The circumstances of my arrival are too suspicious."
"Why are you here?" asked Murder
"I come on behalf of the Elvenking," said Tauriel "He wishes me too join your company and help to protect Cire and the Ring of Smaug, also to give the company new direction. Sauron is using his puppet Saruman to find the crown of Elrond."
"I always thought that would be impossible to obtain," said Henner "Rivendell is too well protected."
"The crown Elrond now wears is not the same one Sauron craves," said Tauriel "That crown was buried long ago, during the time of the forming of the kingdom of Rohan. The crown was buried, and the fortress of Helm's Deep was built atop it. Even now, Saruman prepares to strike at Rohan, Theoden will lead his people to Helm's Deep, the only fortress big enough to protect the whole kingdom. But Saruman's army is tens of thousands of a new breed of orc, Uruk Hai, they will breach Helm's Deep, and they will find the crown, Lord Elrond sends a force to reinforce them, but Lord Thranduil thinks that your group should also head there, perhaps create a diversion, force Saruman to choose what to go after, it is up to you, of course, Princess Cire, as leader of this company, but that is my council."
1521212212122122211211112111221212211.title: continue.

15212122121221222112111121112212122111.content:
The vision you were given of future events in Laketown still had you unnerved. "According to the ancient scrolls, the old crown of Eldron is one of the most important pieces." Frowning, you said. "As much as I desire to defend my kingdom, the existence of the entire world is at stake." You then muttered, "I can only pray I am not making a mistake."

"The Dwarfs of Lonely Mountain are strong allies to your kingdom, princess Cire." Placing a gentle hand on your shoulder, Murder said. "You must stick to your mission; destroy the ring of Smaug before that dreaded dragon is unleashed or worse."

"What could be worse than old Smaug coming back?" Wincing, you asked.

"Smaug's magic can be used by anyone to make themselves 'immortal'." Serious, Tauriel explained. "However, there is a price. You need to take another person's soul to bring your soul back from the dead." she paused. "I heard this machine Sauron craves changes the world; how exactly does the ancient scrolls say it works?"

"The machine is a throne that rests on an altar." Frowning, you said. "The rings of evil power the device. Eldron's old crown has several circles that holds the rings and channels their energy."

"Wait... a throne!?" Startled, Henner asked.

"That's correct." Looking at Henner, you replied. "Several sacrifices are required to work the device. Those who power the rings, and the one who bears the crown." You turned back to Tauriel. "Three wizard staffs are placed into three slots in the altar. One on each side of the throne and one above the throne with a wire connected to the crown."

"Where exactly is this device?" Curious, Murder asked. "Do the ancient scrolls give a clue?"

"That part is sketchy." Wincing, you said. "All the scrolls say was that the forest of Mirkwood was raised around the device to protect it."

"Sauron's forces were spotted deep in Mirkwood before this campaign began." Worried, Tauriel said. "For all we know he may have the cursed thing."

"You said something about the Heart of the mountain being the heart of the machine." Serious, Murder said. "How does that piece come into play?"

"The scrolls say that the heart of the mountain is what casts the old world out and the new world in." Darkly, you said. "It fits onto the very top of the altar." You shivered slightly. "Once all three wizard staffs are pulled with the middle fitting the crown onto the sacrifice, all the energy is channeled through that person and into the heart of the mountain which then seals the 'contract', replacing the old world with the new."

"That is horrifying." Slowly, Tauriel breathed. "The device must never be allowed to be assembled."

The others nodded in agreement. "Then we are off to Helm's Deep." Turning your horse, you said.

152121221212212221121111211122121221113.content:
You brought your horse to the top of the rise, looking into the ravine that held Helm's Deep. Henner and one of her scouts had left some time ago to scout out the land around the fortress and the inside. You had been training with Murder and Tauriel. While you had never fought with two weapons before, you thought you should learn before having to fight an army. Tauriel had been very helpful, as had Murder. Tauriel had led the Mirkwood Rangers, who specialised in the dual weapon fighting style. While Murder preferred her fists, she too had fought with the Rangers for a while, enough to help you practice. Using two ordinary elven blades, instead of Fang and the enchanted ice blade, you picked up the style fast and soon had Tauriel choosing her strikes more carefully.

"Let's call it there," said Tauriel "You fight well, Cire, as you can see, two weapon fighting is a lot more complex and intricate than single weapon fighting, or fighting without weapons."
"You fought well," you said, bowing respectfully "You and Murder are two of a kind, the best fighters I've ever seen."
"I've had a lot of practice," said Tauriel "Even after the assault on Dol Guldur by the White Council, the spiders of Mirkwood continue to plague us, I fought in the Battle of the Five Armies alongside my kin, I thought I was going to die, and I did whatever I could to make sure the people closest to me made it through that battle."
Tauriel looked sad as she finished her speech.
"Who did you lose?" you asked
"I hadn't known him for very long," said Tauriel "In fact, I'd only really met him briefly, but we struck up a friendship that lasted even through the interspecies barrier."
"There's nothing wrong with having a friendship with one of the race of men," you said "I know some elves look down upon it, but some of the greatest stories came about from unions like that."
"If only it were that simple," said Tauriel "But the person I speak of, was a dwarf."
"Oh," you said "Tell me about him."
"His name was Kili," said Tauriel "We were never in love, but we struck up a friendship from either side of a barred cage, friends look out for each other, Kili was injured by a Morgul Shaft as he escaped the Woodland Realm, I knew I could save him, so I followed, I managed to save him, only for him to die in the Battle of the Five Armies."
"I'm sorry," you said "Thank you for sharing it with me."
"Thank you for listening," said Tauriel, giving a small smile, as Henner and the other scout returned.

"Fortress is empty," said Henner "The Rohirrin must still be on the road."
"It is a dangerous road," said Murder "If Saruman has any of the weapons Sauron has, I know exactly what I would do."
"Attack them on the road," you said, already putting one foot in the stirrups of your horse as Murder did the same. Tauriel climbed up behind Murder, drawing one of her long daggers.
You rode off, Murder, Tauriel, Henner and her scouts riding along behind.

1521212212122122211211112111221212211132.content:
The creatures were like nothing you had ever seen before. They had leathery, bat-like wings and spiked tails, their necks were long, and they seemed to glow with an angry red light. Their mouths were filled with flame, behind teeth like stalactites. Atop each of these creatures sits an orc, holding a spear-like staff glowing with the same red light the creatures were. The Rohirrin were shooting at the creatures, but the red lightning around it was stopping the arrows before they even pierced the creature's hides. Several civilians were surrounded by three of the creatures, nowhere else to go, and were standing there, as the creatures circled them.

You rode towards the creatures, drawing Fang and your ice blade, you rode alongside one of them, slashing sideways along it's hide. Unlike the arrows that were still bouncing off the creature's hide, the sword connected, and ice spread over the limb you had slashed at, rendering it immobile. Tauriel, who had been riding with Murder behind you, jumped from the horse and grabbed onto the creature's frozen leg, using her daggers to steady herself as she climbed up. The long-necked creature turned it's head and breathed flame at Tauriel. She jumped to it's other leg and continued climbing, except this time, stabbing her daggers into the creature's leg to haul herself up. When she reached the creature's back, she ran towards the orc sitting on the creature's back, and stabbed it. It shrieked in orcish as it died, and the red light surrounding him and the creature vanished. As it did, several arrows struck the creature in the legs, causing it to fall to the ground in considerable pain. Tauriel jumped off, somersaulting before landing on the next one in the circle, stabbing that one too. Murder, not wanting to be outdone by her sister, called a command to her horse, and it unfurled it's wings. She flew up, avoiding the flame from the creature she was attacking, and slashed clean through the creature's neck.

1521212212122122211211112111221212211132.content:
You knew that guarding the civilians would not stop the orcs or the foul winged creatures they were riding on. They had to be destroyed swiftly and completely only you were not certain how. Just as you were about to blindly charge in, a memory sparked in your mind. You saw your birth father and your birth mother standing on the docks of Laketown. Your father held a burning torch while your mother held an ice blade similar to the one Murder had given you. The placed the two together and fired an impressive beam of fire and ice at the old worm, Smaug. The blast hit the dragon but it was not enough and he fired back with a blast of fire that took them both.

Tears flowed as the memory faded but it gave you an idea. "Smaug was too heavily armored for such a blast but these orcs are paper by comparison!"

You shouted a command to your horse, Arwen and charged forward. Arwen gave a animal battle cry as he leaped onto a pile of rubble to the roof of a stone structure and then into the air as you drew out both Fang and the ice sword. "Taste my fury!"

Both Murder and Tauriel paused as you slammed the two swords together. There was a hollow boom before a powerful stream of both fire and ice fired forth from the swords. A majority of the orcs and their hellish mounts were instantly scorched and frozen at the same time. There was no time for the foul creatures to even scream as their lifeless forms fell to the ground and shattered before vanishing in a blood red light.

Arwen landed on the hard ground and cried out in satisfaction as you then eyed the remaining forces with a battle hungry look. It was just the distraction Murder and Tauriel needed to destroy the last of the attacking forces with the rest of your group joining, being inspired by your surprising power. Within minutes, not a single orc was left standing or in the air. You dismounted Arwen to be confronted by Murder who seemed stunned by your display.

"How in the world did you obtain Elven magic!?" Surprised, she demanded.

You blushed slightly. "My birth father was human, the prince of an island nation beyond the bay of Belfalas." Softly, you explained. "My birth mother was an Elf; the princess of an Elven kingdom beyond the great waters of Belegar."

"You are half Elven?" Surprised, Tauriel asked. "I thought such unions were forbidden due to the great instability of a human's emotions."

"From what my adopted father, King Bard told me, their marriage was not blessed by the two nations but by Elrond of Rivendell. They were married in the kingdom of Dale and my birth father became my adopted father's most trusted second."

Tauriel nodded. "When it comes to true love, riches and prestige are meaningless without the one you hold dear." Smiling slightly, she said. "It's an old Elven quote. It stands behind a strict Elven law. It is not frowned upon for a human and elf fall in love. However, should they bond in marriage, they must start anew on their own."

Murder shook her head. "How about that; you are a true prince." she giggled. "Well, a princess and you are half elven, no less."

"As a female, even half elf, she as magic and it is strong." Her smile broadening, Tauriel.

You fought the tears forming in your eyes. "I remembered my birth mother and father using that trick against Smaug when he attacked Laketown." The tears began to fall. "They failed and Smaug killed them with his fire. Bard took me in as his own and was soon after declared king."

"So you are Elrond's Godson." Whispering, Tauriel said.

"Godson?" Turning to you, Murder asked. "Why was I not told of this?"

"The quest was too important for such distractions." Looking guilty, you replied. "Also, if you recall, I did not wished to be known for my titles."

Murder shook her head, smiling. "You never cease to surprise me... princess."


You blushed brightly then cleared your throat. "Yes... well I suggest we continue on with our quest."

Tauriel gaped at you for a moment then stated, "Um, Cire..."
